text: I'm Rob Mackey I write the lead blog for
the New York Times this week we've been
following very closely events in Iran
we've been trying to supplement the
coverage our correspondents there been
providing by using the internet
specifically been looking a lot at
citizen journalism posted through
Facebook Twitter YouTube Flickr to try
and get some more of a sense of what's
going on on the streets this has been
particularly important because there
have been severe restrictions placed by
the Iranian authorities on the work of
foreign independent media in Iran itself
one of the first pieces of video that we
saw up here on YouTube was on Saturday
showing clashes between opposition
supporters and what seems to be the riot
police in Tehran these kinds of images
are familiar in other parts of Middle
East but we're not used to seeing them
in Iran which is usually a very tightly
controlled society something else we saw
over the weekend was that people outside
Tehran in other cities like Shiraz
mashhad and Tabriz were also recording
opposition protests and posting them
online probably mainly for other people
in Iran to see but also informing the
rest of the world that things were
happening outside of Iran's capital at
the end of Monday's largely peaceful
protest in central Tehran there was a
violent incident where there were
clashes between opposition supporters
and members of a paramilitary militia
called the passage as Monday and Tuesday
war on more and more clips from
different angles people seem to shot on
video cameras but also on cell phones
and still cameras came to light and were
posted on YouTube relying on evidence
based on citizen journalism can be
difficult it's very difficult to verify
in the traditional sense for example on
Wednesday morning we saw photographs
that appeared to be of a rally that was
taking place in the center of Tehran
some of these images were posted through
Twitter on twitpic we were looking at
them and trying to determine whether or
not they were genuine when other images
appeared on YouTube of exactly the same
march in the same location so we had a
good idea that this seemed to
genuinely representing what was
happening wednesday then as the day wore
on we were able to get pictures across
the wires from professional
photographers who are covering the rally
from exactly the same locations on
Friday the Iranian authorities staged a
large rally using the occasion of Friday
prayers to put the supreme leader
Ayatollah Ali Khamenei before a large
number of loyal followers this was all
carried live on state television and
broadcast around the country the
opposition decided not to have a head-on
confrontation on Friday they called off
a planned protest outside the Friday
prayers in Tehran since there was no
opposition rally on Friday Iranian
bloggers didn't have new video 2.2 but
they did want to keep the momentum going
obviously they pointed throughout the
day to videos from mr. Mousavi's
campaign that have been put together to
spread his message with restrictions on
the foreign media is still very much in
effect it does seem likely that if this
weekend brings more large opposition
rallies we're going to depend on citizen
journalists to bring us documentation of
them through the internet
